node.title: Failed to JIT compile expression
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I got a message while executing that I have never seen before:
"*** Info ***
Failed to JIT compile expression, falling back to byte code interpretation." This seems to lead to a fatal error later:
"JIT compile failed.
In file included from /opt/ohpc/pub/compiler/gcc/9.4.0/include/c++/9.4.0/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/bits/c++config.h:528,
                 from /opt/ohpc/pub/compiler/gcc/9.4.0/include/c++/9.4.0/cmath:41,
                 from ./tmp_jit_mpl4ep.cc:2:
/opt/ohpc/pub/compiler/gcc/9.4.0/include/c++/9.4.0/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/bits/os_defines.h:39:10: fatal error: features.h: No such fileor directory
   39 | #include <features.h>"

The weird thing is that I run the same code on another (Linux) machine using the same gnu compiler suite (I think) and there I do not get this message and error.
This issue seems to be not the same as JIT compile error when "too many files open" using ParsedMaterials (tophmatthews #9549). I am using ParsedMaterials,  but only three of them that are also linked: the third one uses the second one which uses the first one.
Any ideas of what is going on here?

Can you share the parsed expression here?
And you have write access to the folder this is running in / permissions set correctly right

Hi Guillaume,
Yes, I have write access to the folder.
Below are the ParsedMaterials. The quantities mur, aparam, Ms are GenericConstantMaterials defined in preceding blocks:
   [./hnorm]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = h_norm
    coupled_variables = 'Hext_x Hext_y Hext_z'#
    expression = 'sqrt((Hext_x)^2+(Hext_y)^2+(Hext_z)^2)'
    execute_on = 'final'
  [../]
  [./Ha]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = Ha
    material_property_names = 'mur Ms h_norm'
    expression = 'max(0.,(mur -1.)*h_norm/Ms)'
    execute_on = 'final'
  [../]
    [./permeability]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = chi
    material_property_names = 'Ms aparam Ha h_norm'
    expression = '0.5*Ms*(Ha +1.-sqrt((Ha+1.)^2-4.*Ha*(1.-aparam)))/((1.-aparam))'
    execute_on = 'final'
  [../]
```
Note that copy and paste missed some * signs for multiplication in the parsed expressions.
formatting got them back

for the last one, can you try:
     material_property_names = 'Ms aparam Ha'
you dont use h_norm
for all, can you please try removing this execute_on = final. I ve never done that on Material

Hi Guillaume. Yeah it looks like the "execute_on" is causing trouble. Removing that line for the ParsedMaterials seems to have made the problem go away. Interesting that the two different computer platforms gave different errors. On my linux workstation (Ubuntu 20.04 and gnu compilers) I did not get a warning about JIT compile and subsequent crash - instead the execution crashed because "unused parameter 'Materials/permeability/execute_on' "

node.title: PorousFlow: how to visualise velocity on surfaces (paraview)
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
Our mesh has surfaces that we apply BCs on them, I want to visualise the velocity normal to the surfaces, is it possible with MOOSE/Paraview?
[./topol_linear_TOPOLSRF_F005_UG1]
type = PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSinkBEH
variable = porepressure
boundary = 'TOPOLSRF_F005_UG1'
pt_vals = '-1e9 1e9'
multipliers = '-1e9 1e9'
flux_function = 1
v = min_dist
PT_shift = -9810
fluid_phase = 0
[../]


I know I can visualise the surface via Sets on Paraview, but I only can show node properties (velocity is a mesh property)

Is there a way to work around this (like project element velocity value to the element surface [normal multiply?])?
Thank you very much!
Kind regards,
Traiwit

Hello
You ll want to look at auxkernels for that.
Create a new auxiliary variable vec_times_n, const monomial
Then in the auxkernel, also boundary restricted, you can set the value with velocity * _normal
You ll want the DIffusionFluxAux but change from grad_u to just _u.
There might be one already somewhere, but cant seem to find it
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud,
Thank you for a reply, to start, should I create another object based on DIffusionFluxAux and follow what you mentioned?


vec_times_n, const monomial


set the value with velocity * _normal


change from grad_u to just _u.


Kind regards,
Traiwit

I would do that yes.
vec_times_n, const monomial -> just an input file change
New auxkernel (named: AdvectiveFluxAux)

parameters: vx vy vz as params.addCoupledVar
coupled variables v_xyz set as v_x(coupledValue("vx")
return RealVectorValue(v_x[_qp], v_y[_qp], v_z[_qp]) * _normals[_qp]

i'm still a bit confused, where does it take the velocity data from?

Do you not have velocity non linear variables?
And if not, cant porous flow compute them from the pressure field?

and how do I visualise this data?

You visualize it on the whole domain, then use the threhshold filter in paraview to only show the nonzero cells. They will all be near the boundary

Do you not have velocity non linear variables?
And if not, cant porous flow compute them from the pressure field?

hmm i'm using this to compute Velocity PorousFlowDarcyVelocityComponent
[./darcy_x]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./darcy_y]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[./darcy_z]
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[]


[AuxKernels]
[./darcy_x]
type = PorousFlowDarcyVelocityComponent
variable = darcy_x
gravity = '0 0 -9.81'
component = x
[../]
[./darcy_y]
type = PorousFlowDarcyVelocityComponent
variable = darcy_y
gravity = '0 0 -9.81'
component = y
[../]
[./darcy_z]
type = PorousFlowDarcyVelocityComponent
variable = darcy_z
gravity = '0 0 -9.81'
component = z
[../]
[]

I'm still not sure, I will get back to you once there's an error.

You visualize it on the whole domain, then use the threhshold filter in paraview to only show the nonzero cells. They will all be near the boundary

This makes sense, thanks!
Kind regards,
Traiwit

darcy_xyz could serve as the v_xyz parameters then I think.
btw if you feel like making a pull request this auxkernel could go in the moose/framework. We are keen on external contributions
How is the sideset oriented? The _normal attribute will depend on that

How is the sideset oriented? The _normal attribute will depend on that

I think it kinda makes sense now, it positive becase the velocity is flowing outward respect to the surface (hence positive) not to the xyz space. on the other hands if the flow is inward into the surface, it will be positive (i guess)

above is the surface where I apply BCs
[./drain_DRAINSRF_F008_UG4] 
type = PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSinkBEH 
variable = porepressure 
boundary = 'DRAINSRF_F008_UG4'
pt_vals = '0 1e9' 
multipliers = '0 1e9' 
flux_function = 1
v = min
PT_shift = 0 
use_mobility = true
fluid_phase = 0
[../]

I think it kinda makes sense now, it positive becase the velocity is flowing outward respect to the surface (hence positive) not to the xyz space. on the other hands if the flow is inward into the surface, it will be positive (i guess)

yes, as long as the sideset is consistently oriented
how is that surface/sideset defined? using a commercial mesher?
Does it consistently point the same direction?
We unfortunately do not currently have a way (coming this summer is the plan) to look at sideset directions from MOOSE

node.title: A general question about preconditioner
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I had a general question about the preconidtioner.


What is the difference between MOOSE and PETSC preconditioner? why we need to use them both?


Considering the below setup, what does the sub_pc mean? So we have a pc and sub_pc. What is the purpose of using both of them here. For example, what will happen if we do not use a sub_pc?


    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_asm_overlap -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_levels -sub_pc_factor_shift_type'
   petsc_options_value = 'asm      2               ilu          4                     NONZERO'

Thanks,
Ali

Hello
A MOOSE 'preconditioner' is just setting the right parameters for a PETSc preconditioner.
For the more complex PETSc preconditioners, we have set up interfaces in MOOSE that can check parameters or make sure the PETSc parameters are passed in the desired order or with some more parameters tied to the size of the system that would not naturally be passed by a user.
Many preconditioners are naturally composable and the sub_ option lets you specify options on each block (numerical)
For example see this page explaining the sub_ options for asm: https://petsc.org/release/manualpages/PC/PCGASM/
Guillaume

Thank you very much!
Ali

node.title: Csv file
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I wanted to get a csv file that includes data for the whole domain (2D) for, I have got earlier a csv file that includes variations only on x axis but when I wanted to do so for both axis (all domain) I did not manage to :
[VectorPostprocessors]
  [t_sampler]
    type = LineValueSampler
    variable = temperature
    start_point = '0 0 0'
    end_point = '0.00008 0.000005 0'
    num_points = 20
    sort_by = x y

Thanks

Hello
Right now you only have something along (0,0) -> (0.00008 0.000005)
If you have a 2D domain, you may consider this instead:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/ElementValueSampler.html
Which will sample every element
or
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/NodalValueSampler.html
for every node
We are in need of a PlaneValueSampler if you have time to build one and contribute it.
Guillaume

node.title: An error occurred in calculating the generalized plane strain of the ring: Index out of bounds!
node.bodyText:
I ran into an error while calculating the generalized plane strain problem for a ring, and I was wondering why this error occurs and how to fix it. Here is my input card.
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh
  file = halo.e
[]

[Variables]
  [./temp]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 553.15
  [../]
  [./disp_x]
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
  [../]
  [./scalar_strain_zz]
    order = FIRST
    family = SCALAR
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
  [./power_profile]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    data_file = power_halo.csv
    format = columns
  [../]
  [./shape]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 8.0e7
  [../]
  [./q]
    type = CompositeFunction
    functions = 'power_profile shape'
  [../]
  [./gap_conductance]
    type =  ParsedFunction
    value = '-1.8275e-4*t+3500'
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./ht]
    type = HeatConduction
    variable = temp
    block = halo
  [../]
  [./h_dt]
    type = HeatConductionTimeDerivative
    variable = temp
    block = halo
  [../]
  [./hs]
    type = HeatSource
    variable = temp
    block = halo
    function = q
  [../]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    use_displaced_mesh = false
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    temperature = temp
    block = halo
  [../]
[]

[Modules]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    [./GeneralizedPlaneStrain]
      [./fuel]
        use_displaced_mesh = true
        displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
        scalar_out_of_plane_strain = scalar_strain_zz
        block = halo
      [../]
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./den]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    block = halo
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = 10960.0
  [../]
  [./hc]
    type = HeatConductionMaterial
    block = halo
    temperature = temp
    thermal_conductivity = 9.0
    specific_heat = 350.0
  [../]
  [./ev]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    block = halo
    poissons_ratio = 0.316
    youngs_modulus = 2.1e11
  [../]
  [./strain]
    type = ComputePlaneSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    scalar_out_of_plane_strain = scalar_strain_zz
    block = halo
    eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain
  [../]
  [./thermal_eigen_strain]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    block = halo
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain
    stress_free_temperature = 298.0
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 1e-5
  [../]
  [./stress]
    type = ComputeStrainIncrementBasedStress
    block = halo
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./outer_temp]
    type = ConvectiveFluxFunction
    variable = temp
    boundary = 'ri ro'
    T_infinity = 393.0
    coefficient_function = gap_conductance
    coefficient = 1.0
  [../]
  [./no_disp_x]
     type = DirichletBC
     variable = disp_x
     boundary = 'obottom ibottom otop itop'
     value = 0.0
  []
  [./no_disp_y]
     type = DirichletBC
     variable = disp_y
     boundary = 'oleft ileft oright iright'
     value = 0.0
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./disp_p1]
    type = PointValue
    point = '4.95e-3 0.0 0.0'
    variable = disp_x
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
  [./disp_p2]
    type = PointValue
    point = '7.05e-3 0.0 0.0'
    variable = disp_x
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
  [./temp_p2]
    type = PointValue
    point = '6.0e-3 0.0 0.0'
    variable = temp
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap -ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm lu 20 101'

  l_max_its = 10
  l_tol = 1e-4

  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_max_its = 10

  dtmax = 1e5
  dtmin = 1e-3
  end_time = 4.2e6
  automatic_scaling = true
  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1000
    optimal_iterations = 10
    iteration_window = 4
    linear_iteration_ratio = 10
  [../]
[]
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]
@GiudGiud Do you know what caused this error?
I cant run your input file could you please share your mesh?

I cant run your input file could you please share your mesh?

halo.zip
power_halo.csv
There are my mesh and power file. Thank you very much.

runs 'fine' for me
just start with a 10s time step instead of a big one and let it grow later
also let the solver take more iterations
  l_max_its = 100
  nl_max_its = 100

BUT
the results dont look right, and that s probably because the mesh has artefacts

runs 'fine' for me
just start with a 10s time step instead of a big one and let it grow later also let the solver take more iterations
  l_max_its = 100
  nl_max_its = 100

BUT the results dont look right, and that s probably because the mesh has artefacts 

I used this method run it but still met same error.
I realized maybe becaused moose that I installed was old version. So I ran this case again in the latest version of moose and found error disappeared. The results was same as yours.




This was due to a problem with my heat source settings, and I got reasonable results after I corrected the heat source. Thank you again.

node.title: Grain growth model with inclination dependence
node.bodyText:
Hi I am new to MOOSE and I would like to use it for developin a multi-phase field model for grain growth with inclination dependence. I would like to basically reproduce the results shown in this paper (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.actamat.2020.02.043). I have read the documentation quite extensively and followed some tutorials and examples, but I find that many of the parts regarding multi-phase field models are still not totally documented and I find myself lost in trying to implement the model.
Could I get some basic guidance into trying to implement this? I am particularly interested in including the grain-boundary energy terms shown into the linked paper (Seciton 2.2), into the Free-Energy expression.
@dschwen @permcody any thoughts?
@jiangwen84 @laagesen

Hi @oarcelus, thanks for your interest in the MOOSE framework! As you noted, we do not have much implemented in the phase-field module for multi-phase field models such as the one you linked to. I wonder if you have considered a multi-order parameter approach instead? We do have a lot more implemented in MOOSE using a multi-order parameter strategy, primarily using this model:
https://journals.aps.org/prb/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevB.78.024113
This model can include misorientation and inclination dependence. So, I think that either a multi-phase field or multi-order parameter approach could simulate the physics you are interested in; there would just be a lot more already implemented if you chose the multi-order parameter approach. There might still be some code that would need to be implemented depending on what inclination-dependent features you want to add, there would just be a lot more you could build on.

Hi @laagesen, thank you for your comment. In fact, I read the paper you just linked, as well as the last one by N. Moelans (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264127522002131?via%3Dihub) for which I found some MOOSE implementation (https://github.com/PengWei97/yinglong), which apparently also solves for some known issue regarding the use of GrainTracker and GBAnisotropy? (not sure of this latter one).
In any case, I am still a bit confused about all this digging (jumping fresh into this giant software can be confusing...). So I will post a few more questions here:


I fail to understand the difference between 'multi-phase' and 'multi-order parameter'. In which way the paper I originally linked is considered 'multi-phase' and the ones by N.Moelans are not? They both state some sort of free energy and they solve for the time evolution of non-conserved parameters through a first derivative of time and a functional derivative of the free-energy with respect to the order parameters. The only difference I see is that in the paper I linked there are some extra-higher order terms, which will probably be a nightmare to treat in code, but other than that nothing more.


The 'GrainTracker' functionallity is 'in principle' only used to improve the computational performance of the models right? You could in principle make a grain growth model considering explicitly all of the order parameters, then a single Kernel would take care of all the interactions, since they are the same. What the GrainTracker does is to make it so that no two order parameters are contiguous (so that tails do not overlap), and you can reduce their number.  If so, is there any functionallity to merge grains as there is in GrainTracker, but without actually using GrainTracker?


In the link I originally sent there is some pretty straightforward formulas linking the grain-boundary energy to the grain inclination, making it a continuous function. Is there a way of implementing this in a simple way? I guess that I also have an understanding gap between the terms 'misorientation' and 'inclination'.


Sorry for the long post, but these conversations are really useful to me, and thanks again for the response!

Let me try to answer questions by number:

Multi-phase field models usually refers to models where the phase field represents the phase fraction and the phase-fields are required to sum to 1 at every position. Multi-order parameter models do not enforce such a restriction. Some people feel that in the multi-phase field models, the direct correspondence between the phase field variables and phase fraction makes the model more physical, but I think that if you are interested in simulating grain growth, it is more important that the Allen-Cahn evolution equations approach the evolution equations for grain growth in the sharp interface limit (for grain growth, this is that grain boundary velocity is proportional to local curvature). This has been done in the Moelans paper I referred to, I am sure it has also been done for multi-phase field models but I don't know a good reference for that off-hand. Several years ago there was a paper comparing multi-phase field and multi-order parameter approaches for simulating grain growth, I believe Steinbach and Moelans were among the co-authors, so if you do a search of Web of Science you can probably track that down (sorry I don't have the reference handy off hand here either).
You are right on the purpose of the GrainTracker. The only thing I would say is I am not sure what you mean by "a single Kernel would take care of all the interactions" - a Kernel in MOOSE parlance represents a single term in an equation. So if you had Allen-Cahn equations for every order parameter, you would need additional kernels to represent each term in each Allen-Cahn equation. This may be confusing because adding Kernels is hidden in the grain growth example input files because we use Actions, namely the PolycrystalKernelAction, which automates adding kernels to the input files.
Misorientation vs. inclination has to do with the 5 degrees of freedom of a grain boundary, which you may want to refer to a materials science textbook on. I believe misorientation refers to the 3 possible ways (angles) of orienting the crystals relative to each other, while inclination refers to the plane that cuts the two crystals which I think are two. If you can post an example of exactly what type of function you are wanting to implement, I can try to give some more specifics on how it could be implemented or if we have something similar already implemented.

Just to want to give the reference mentioned in point 1
Moelans, Nele, Frank Wendler, and Britta Nestler. "Comparative study of two phase-field models for grain growth." Computational Materials Science 46.2 (2009): 479-490. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S092702560900158X
thank you!
especially since I was incorrect on the co-authors! :-)

node.title: Thermal contact analytical benchmark
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
Somewhere in the MOOSE documentation or an MOOSE-based app documentation, I remember seeing a benchmark for thermal contact problem. The example was modelling two bars (made of aluminum and steel) in contact and heat was flowing in from one end. At the contact between aluminum and steel, there is a discontinuity in temperature. Assuming that the bars were infinite analytical solution was derived and compared with MOOSE solution. They both agreed very well.
Even after hours of searching it, I am not able to find it. Can anybody help ?
Thanks

We have this detailed verification problem and accompanying analytical solution in MALAMUTE that @cticenhour prepared: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/malamute/verification/thermal_contact_verification.html If that is the benchmark problem to which you were referring, would you move any follow-on discussion to the MALAMUTE-specific discussion please?
We also have the analytical solution for heat transfer as a function of pressure on this documentation page in MOOSE: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/GapFluxModelPressureDependentConduction.html and the regression test is linked on that page.
Hope this helps,
Stephanie
Thank you Stephanie @sapitts . That's the one I wanted.
